results.title: Drifting
results.brief_description: Looks at the British herring-fishing, ports drift-fishers in port, and leaving for the fishing grounds. Shows in detail the process of catching the herring.

results.title: Drifters
results.creator_credit: Empire Marketing Board and John Grierson
results.brief_description: The only film ever directed personally by John Grierson. A documentary made for the Empire Marketing Board about the men of the British herring fleets. ‘Drifters’ brought to the screen the labour of the North Sea herring fleet in such a way that the ordinary man or woman was made to realise, perhaps for the first time, that the herring on his plate was no mere accident, but the result of the labour and courage of other men.

results.title: Dressing up in the past
results.creator_credit: David Ferris, Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Presents Lorri Baines, National Gallery Education Officer, demonstrating what the gallery offers children in terms of the history of clothing and costume. Using two children as models she shows how eighteen century aristocrats would have dressed and the restrictions imposed by their mode of dress.

results.title: Dressed to kill
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures and Roy William Neill
results.brief_description: Adapted from a story by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and featuring the inimitable Sherlock Holmes (Basil Rathbone) and his sidekick, Dr Watson (Nigel Bruce). In this tale of mystery and suspense, Holmes has to find the whereabouts of three wooden music boxes containing Bank of England engraving plates in order to prevent certain crims out there from basically obtaining a licence to print money. Cast includes Patricia Morison, Edmond Breon, Frederick Worlock, Carl Harbord, Patricia Cameron.

results.title: Dressed for the part
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and Ronald Gardner
results.brief_description: The increasingly important role of safety committees in watching for sources of danger to the worker and seeing that adequate protection is provided. Types of protective clothing for acid handling, welding, lathe work, drum handling and working at heights are shown in use. The film ends with a reminder that while safety committees are doing a good job, their work is ineffective unless the equipment they provide is used by those for whom it was designed.

results.title: Dress for Success
results.brief_description: Each year the final students at Sydney’s design colleges compete for a fashion design award. In 1991 the theme was for an evening dress which reflected the multicultural heritage of Australia. The judges, students and teachers comment on the designs themselves, the state of the fashion industry in Australia and their own personal hopes and dreams.

results.title: Dreams of success
results.creator_credit: Peter Griffiths, Ron Tanner and Millbank Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Starting your own business”.
This film is the first in a series which sets out to bring home to all those who are considering self-employment that there is no easy or simple recipe for success. The film tells the stories of three people who decide to try to be their own boss. Many basic business points are made, and the main intention is to identify the problems and pitfalls of going it alone.

results.title: Dreams of return
results.creator_credit: Julie Shiels, North Richmond Community Health Centre, Timorese Association of Victoria and Michael Buckley
results.brief_description: This CDROM has been funded by the Australian Film Commission and is primarily about the experiences of Timorese refugees living in Australia. The work is a contemporary look at identity, resistance and the dream of return to East Timor. The CDROM is shaped around the performance and cultural work (including dance, drumming and storytelling) developed by members of the East Timorese community who are based at the North Richmond community health centre. The work in this CDROM was developed in conjunction with the Timorese association of Victoria.

results.title: Dreams come true: interviews with Glen Keane and Lella Smith
results.brief_description: ACMI curator, Emma McRae interviews Glen Keane and Lella Smith as part of the ‘Disney : dreams come true’ exhibition at ACMI. Glen Keane is an animator for Disney and has created some of the recent best-loved characters such as Ariel from ‘The Little mermaid’ and ‘The Beast’ from ‘Beauty and the beast’. Lella Smith is the creative director of Disney’s Animation Research Library and was a curator for the ‘Disney : dreams come true’ exhibition. These interviews were recorded at ACMI in conjunction with the opening of the exhibition.

results.title: Dreams and silence = Reves et silences
results.creator_credit: Sourat Films, FR3, CBA and Omar Al-Qattan
results.brief_description: It is the autumn of 1990 in Jordan. The Islamic movement has declared a Holy War against the West and the Gulf War is at its height. Haifa Samhouri is a middle-aged Palestinian refugee living in Jordan. In this sensitively produced and directed documentary, Haifa talks of her life as a refugee, her love for her homeland, her arranged and loveless marriage, her sons, and her continuing philosophical battle with her religion, Islam, which on the one hand offers salvation and on the other, oppression, especially towards women. Bitter at times but often displaying an ironic sense of humour we see Haifa as she goes about her daily life, confronting, questioning her husband and male neighbours about the role of women within the Islamic faith but also prepared to sacrifice her son in the war if it means winning the war. Juxtaposed to Haifa’s story, is a discourse by an Islamic spiritual leader on the political and philosophical aspects of Islam against the background of the suffering and destruction of the Arab world and the aftermath of the Gulf War. Winner of several awards including Joris Ivens Award (1st prize) International Documentary Film Festival, Amsterdam 1991 and Honorary prize, Best Documentary, Valencia Film Festival, 1991. In Arabic with English and French subtitles.
